rules: Rule1: If legislation protects artwork, then cultural heritage benefits the community.
Rule2: Either legislation protects artwork or legislation preserves natural places.
Rule3: Either tourism damages heritage sites or, in the event that cultural shows attract tourism, cultural heritage benefits the community.
Rule4: Under the condition that an organization monitors a heritage site, it alerts authorities.
Rule5: Either the organization monitors the heritage site or the authority inspects the heritage site.
Rule6: If the authority inspects the heritage site, then tourism does not damage the heritage site.
Rule7: Whenever the organization documents the condition, tourism does not damage the heritage site.
Rule8: The organization reports findings only if it documents the condition.
Rule9: The organization alerts authorities only if it reports findings.
Rule10: If the government implements policy, then the authority enforces policy.
Rule11: If the committee reviews policy, then, provided that attracting cultural shows to tourism does not imply cultural heritage benefits the community, tourism declines in the region.
Rule12: The government repeals legislation only if it replaces legislation.
Rule13: Either the government repeals legislation or, if the authority enforces policy, then the committee reviews policy.
Rule14: If legislation restricts the region, then it designates a heritage site.
Rule15: Provided that legislation designates a heritage site, the government neglects the heritage site.
Rule16: Whenever legislation designates a heritage site, development demolishes the heritage site.
Rule17: Under the condition that legislation designates a heritage site, conservation conserves the heritage site.
Rule18: Either the government funds conservation or, if conservation conserves the heritage site, then development does not demolish the heritage site.
Rule19: If legislation promotes cultural shows, then cultural heritage benefits the community.
Rule20: Either legislation promotes cultural shows or the region supports cultural shows.
Rule21: The region supports cultural shows only if they attract tourism.
Rule22: If it is not true that preserving natural places by legislation results in cultural heritage benefiting the community, then legislation restricts the region.
Rule23: In the event that designating a heritage site by legislation does not imply the government does not neglect the heritage site, the community protests neglect.
Rule24: If it is not the case that designating a heritage site by legislation leads to the government not neglecting the heritage site, then the community does not protest neglect.
facts: Fact2: Tourism does not decline in the region.
Fact3: The government does not replace legislation.
Fact4: The government does not fund conservation.
